text: thank you thank you for coming to my talk today so
this is my i think second or third event since the pandemic so it's really fun to be back in person with everybody and i
do love copenhagen i've been here twice before for two other go-to conferences and it's an amazing city so i'm going to
talk today about the future of flight and we're working on specifically at my company hydroplane and if i can ask you
a favor um we do need more twitter followers if you consider following the twitter account for a hydroplane error
i'd appreciate it i have enough turtle followers myself so i've been trying to retweet stuff on my own account because
it's good for pr so my background is i did spend the majority of my career working for the
space program at nasa's jet propulsion laboratory all my degrees are in aerospace engineering and my phd is in
propulsion systems so that's the reason why i can teach and talk about rocket science and i did spend several years
working on the development of launch vehicle propulsion systems and then plasma propulsion systems for deep space
exploration and i think i gave a talk at go to a couple of years ago regarding mars entry descent and landing systems i
did that for a few years and after working for nasa for about 20 years i decided to go back into the private
sector because i had originally started off at boeing and specifically work on the development of green transportation
systems i spent about two years working as an executive at a hyperloop technology company i spoke about that i
think in 2019 here at go to perhaps berlin and then i worked in the
battery-powered aircraft space in evitol application for about two years and now
i have a new venture which is focused on power plant technology for electric aircraft specifically hydrogen fuel cell
power plant technology and i'm also a very active pilot and one of the things that i did during the pandemic is i
became a search and rescue pilot for the civil air patrol in the u.s that was allowed me to do something to help
besides just sitting at home you know behind my computer doing zoom meetings all day so it's been quite a bit of fun but i do take the inspiration for what i
do from my space program training and ironically i do also take inspiration from the fact that you know we know a
lot about the earth and climate change because of nasa missions and so now in the second half of my career it's
actually important for me to focus my engineering my leadership and my entrepreneurial skills on addressing
technologies to combat climate change and i'm a huge fan of the space program a huge space get myself but we do have
to think about how we can focus our goals and our technology developments to help us here on earth and i think there
is relevance in what you know prince william said a few weeks ago about like is it really important for us to be focusing on space tourism or perhaps we
should focus on solving challenges here at home and i would agree with that and you could actually take inspiration for
that message from the space program so this image here is actually obviously earth our planet in the middle venus is
uh one planet in from us closer to the sun and mars is one planet out and what we know is that these three planets have
experienced climate change at a planetary scale so they were all similar to each other at the formation of solar
system but now if you take a look at vetus it actually has a surface temperature of around 475 degrees
centigrade and a surface pressure 100 times the surface pressure on earth because it experienced
basically a planetary level greenhouse gas effect and mars on the other hand has a surface pressure of about one
percent here on earth um and has no appreciable water on the surface so we know that by looking at our own
terrestrial plants we can see kind of the um you know end scale effects of different phenomenology that led to
these particular climate change uh fiascos but it's something we have to think about as we move forward with how
we're going to function as a species but i am a huge fan of aviation i've worked on it for a
large portion of my career i think it's one of the most amazing inventions that human beings have come up with and have ultimately led to space travel
and if you go back and look in the history of how flight first started specifically powered flight it was done
by the wright brothers in the united states and a lot of people didn't think it was going to be possible or they could do it even famous physicists such
as lord kelvin said you know such a thing which is lifting body aerodynamics powered flight wasn't possible and of
course these bicycle enthusiasts proved that it was the case um you know over 100 years ago which the message here of
course is that just because something is difficult doesn't mean it can't be done you just have to have the drive and the motivation behind it and i myself got
into engineering aerospace engineering because of my love of the space program because of my love of science fiction
i'm well known to be a huge star trek fan and i think you do take a lot of inspiration for coming up with amazing
ideas by taking a look at the technologies that are first invented in science fiction and then become reality
here at home and i probably am more of a fan of the utopian science fiction model
which is that using technology for good using technology to make the world a better place and i think during the
pandemic we saw a great demonstration of that with the development of the mrna technology for vaccines so technology
certainly can be used for good and can be used to make the world a better place but as i'm a science fiction fan there's
a whole other regime of science fiction which is dystopian science fiction this is taken from the most recent blade runner movie which
represents a possible future for los angeles when things get out of control whether it's from wars or from what we
do to the environment so we do have to think about these two possible futures that we are at a precipice of facing
right now because of climate change and a lot of work is being done to decarbonize travel on the ground with
electric vehicles which are typically battery powered but not so much is being done to decarbonize aviation because
it's a lot more difficult thing to do batteries as a technology can't actually support flight because they're too heavy
whereas you don't have that problem for a ground-based vehicle so other technologies are needed to decarbonize
aviation and the other challenge with aircraft of course is that in addition to putting out co2 if they're operating
off of hydrocarbons they also put out other by-products and they put it up higher in altitude in the environment
which has more of an effect on climate change than ever co2 which is produced on the ground the good news of course
about commercial aviation is that it is a form of mass transit so if the aircraft are filled you can reduce the
co2 output per passenger kilometer to be relatively low for an international flight if you compared it to doing the
same thing with a boat or if you had it ground-based transportation across you know a continental distance but we do
need to address the power plant we do need to reduce the reliance on hydrocarbons and eventually eliminate
them to be able to get us to our climate targets and as everyone here in the room knows as you're part of the european
union that there are goals for 2050 to reduce carbon output which requires decarbonization for everything from
energy for heating your home electricity for providing it to your businesses having more electric vehicles on the
road whether that's in buses trains or cars and we also need to develop those technologies for aircraft going forward
the good news of course is that aviation only represents a small percentage of the total co2 output you know a few
percent but as the other forms of technology are decarbonized you then start to look at aviation as a primary
contributor moving forward and if anyone knows anything about aircraft they're you know complex to design complex to
certify it usually takes many years to be able to get the government regulatory agency to approve what you're doing
which means that you have to have at least a 10-year time constant ahead to develop these technologies to get them
into the private sector for commercial travel so that means now is the time to invest in decarbonization technologies
for aviation and another piece of good news is that sustainability is very much tied
to electricity just like we have electric vehicles on the ground we can have electric aircraft they just can't
be powered by batteries they have to be powered by something which is a higher energy density and what electricity
gives you is several advantages one of them anyone in the room a pilot or fly small aircraft or fly in small aircraft
a few so everybody knows that the primary costs for flying would be fuel and then of course maintenance so if
you're able to remove a traditional internal combustion engine whether that's a turbine or piston-powered
engine um you're actually able to reduce the majority of your maintenance costs for your aircraft so if you shipped over
to an electric power plant with an electric motor you have fewer moving parts you have a reduced maintenance
schedule and you have lower cost for maintenance which is important for both the owner and the operator and aviation
of course is a business venture which means that people want to reduce their operational costs the other advantage to
having an electric powertrain is that electric motors have no moving parts which means they can be more reliable
which means you could have a longer period of time before having to replace them and that also reduces costs and it
increases safety because you're less likely to have an engine failure now an electric drivetrain if powered by a form
of stored electricity on board will obviously have no carbon output so you can address climate change and global
warming reduce and eliminate your co2 output from the aircraft itself as well as all the secondary more noxious
emissions and another benefit for those people who live in an urban environment where there may be an airport nearby is
that when you shift over to an electric power plant you have less noise being produced by the aircraft and so one of
the things that people on the ground don't like about airports and airplanes is the noise being produced so if you get rid of that
internal combustion engine and you replace it with an electric motor you also have reduced noise emissions so you
can see how there's many benefits to shifting to electric aircraft in addition to
the one related to reducing your co2 output but i think this is important and all of you
would know this in the software space when you want to develop a new product you don't start with the final product with all the bells and whistles you
start with something simpler and you build up on your capabilities and your knowledge and you improve that product
and so there's also an evolutionary use case towards electric flight and we already have electric flight today in
the form of unmanned aerial systems or drones which are used for surveillance
some types of aerial reconnaissance as well as perhaps delivery of small packages but those drones are very range
limited in the sense they can only fly for a few minutes so that doesn't really support the use case of transporting
lots of goods and people over large distances but when you also think about other aviation use cases that can become
electrified um there's a whole bunch of them which we use today such as myself who's a general aviation airport pilot
when i fly small single-engine aircraft those same single-engine aircraft can be used for air taxis and they're also used
for emergency response humanitarian aid and disaster relief so all those platforms because they're smaller they
weigh less they have smaller power plants they're more suitable to put in an electric air
electric power plant today on the given day now once you get that up and running you get the faa you got i assets you
approve it then you can think about larger power plants to support things like rotorcraft support things like twin
turboprop aircraft and eventually to develop the technologies to support jet aircraft and so this is the evolutionary
use case towards electric flight which can happen is happening it needs to happen to support the climate targets
for 2050 that we're looking at but we have to develop the needed electricities and so green electricity
also requires energy storage also requires energy production and so the
good news there's a huge movement of foot around the world for renewable energy production whether that's from solar farms or wind farms and that
supports really nicely what i'll talk about next which is the generation of hydrogen but on board the aircraft itself you can't use solar panels
because they're not energy dense they're not as efficient enough you would basically require an incredibly long wingspan and that wouldn't fit in the
context of most airports and you'll only be able to carry one or two people um and then batteries of course are very
heavy which means that you can't use them for long-range applications either so battery aircraft that exist today can
only fly for you know 30 to 60 minutes which doesn't support the range of use cases there is a movement of foot to go
with sustainable aviation fuels but that is still co2 being output just less per passenger kilometer than what you have
today and there's also a potential where you could have a hydra hybrid electric power plant like they did with the first
toyota priuses but once again you're still having a co2 output so that really doesn't address the gold to get to zero
carbon output so the real solution to this is to go with hydrogen fuel cell systems which allows you to have green
energy and output which is carbon free and give you the energy density that you need to support the total energy storage
requirements for aviation and the good news with regards to hydrogen is it's actually the most abundant element in
the universe so it powers our sun um it was you know the first thing that was formed during the big bang 14 was a
trillion years ago and so there's no shortage of a supply of hydrogen you know from a universe perspective
but you have to be able to produce it here on earth in a way which is green in a way which is clean and the way you do
that is with electrolysis so you basically take water which is h2o you apply electricity to it you split it
and then you generate hydrogen in the process so there is a movement of foot in europe actually mainly to come up
with large facilities that will do electrolysis we'll take seawater desalinate it
use electrolysis to produce hydrogen in that green way and that's really good news because for
many places that have for example offshore wind farms they have a lot of excess capacity of renewable electricity
and that can go directly into electrolyzers which then provide hydrogen which can be used as an energy carrier for things like aviation for
things like ground transport or even for home heating and energy storage for you know local
cities and things like that and what i think is really interesting is the word hydrogen itself means in ancient greek
the generation of water so that's where hydrogenesis comes from is hydrogen so
everybody knew that hydrogen was involved in creating water for a really long time and if you think about it in
the context of an aircraft if you're powered off of hydrogen instead of having a byproduct which is co2 the
byproduct of your aircraft is now water which obviously is carbon emission free so it's kind of the you know the holy
grail solution um from an energy density perspective and the other what comes back to rocket science of course is that
the most efficient launch vehicles are also powered off of hydrogen they're carried off of liquid hydrogen and
liquid oxygen so you can't get a better more energy dense carrier than hydrogen
for whatever you want to do especially for vertical takeoff landing applications as well as launch vehicles
as well as aviation applications now i've spent the past two years
in hydrogen space specifically focused on understanding the infrastructure side and how that can transfer over to
aviation which is the company that i have founded and the good news is that the eu has tremendous amount of
investment in this which is producing hydrogen green hydrogen by electrolysis
and they're putting a lot of money in the form of investments of you know billions of dollars into
power plants which are going to make hydrogen for a variety of use cases and it can help to decarbonize ground
transport right in the united states we already have electric cars which are powered by hydrogen fuel cells it can also help to
decarbonize marine and the aviation sector and there's a lot of people
working on this in the public policy arena you know coupled to the engineering side and what is nice about the technology with regards to hydrogen
fuel cells is that from an energy perspective and from a weight of the vehicle perspective both the marine the
aviation and the large vehicle family fall into the same category of needs so
you can develop a single technology potentially hydrogen fuel cells at a certain power range to support these
multiple use cases which is important right because if you're going to expend capital to develop new technology you
want to have a lot of customers who are going to use it and so when you look at the hydrogen fuel cell economy so this
is basically an energy storage economy focused on hydrogen you've got multiple players
i won't go into the boring details of aviation specific but you do require energy storage on the field at an
airport in the form of an auxiliary auxiliary power unit which is currently powered with a gas generator which obviously has a big co2 output that can
be powered by hydrogen unmanned aerial systems could also be powered by hydrogen have a larger payload capacity
a range potential and then the marine sector which i'm sure people in denmark know quite a bit about um you know we
want to shift over to boats which are powered by hydrogen either direct drive or fuel cells and that would help to you
know decarbonize the marine sector which is also a pretty big co2 contributor automotive is an important one so right
now we've got battery powered electric cars but that only works for small cars you have to have hydrogen fuel cells to
go with buses and trucks and trains potentially the hyperloop and then of course there's the space application use
of hydrogen fuel cells which we're also interested in and can be used for the hyperloop which is the company i used to
work for several years ago and there's a great history of use of hydrogen fuel
cell from the space program the space shuttle which is perhaps before the many people's time in the room actually used
hydrogen fuel cells as their energy storage as opposed to battery so lots of space program usage in space of course
you don't have access to air which means you have to carry oxygen on board but that's just a requirement for anything
that's going to be operating off of oxygen for a space environment and it can be used to power spacecraft and it
could be used to power things like mars airplanes for example because batteries once again just don't
have the energy density to provide you with long duration flights but you can take a lot of history and heritage from
the space program and implement them into this new area and so the reason why hydrogen is so wonderful is best shown
from this graphic which is a bit much to read the one on the left but on the lower left you see the lithium ion
battery which basically is the worst performing energy storage you can possibly imagine yet we see it used
ubiquitously you can see diesel and gasoline up to the top and then you can see hydrogen
on the right so hydrogen has the most energy per unit mass the challenge however is that it is a very uh not
dense gas which means it has a volumetric challenge you have to store hydrogen in a compressed state whether
that's as a compressed gas or as a liquid or in some chemically bonded form in order to be able to get it onto a
vehicle but another i think graphical way of thinking about the energy density of hydrogen is with this bar chart here
so this is hydrogen compared to natural gas so you basically you're looking at three times uh the energy per unit mass
using hydrogen versus natural gas so that's great right from a efficiency perspective you can't get any better and
also it's great because you don't have any co2 output so naturally it makes sense to shift over to this as an energy
carrier for humanity going forward but that does require a lot of investment it requires a lot of business justification
and it requires um to be honest with you government's um setting regulation to make that happen which certainly it's
happening the movement is afoot now you can simply use a chemical reaction which is hydrogen interacting with oxygen
which generates heat which you can then use to expand out of a nozzle or you can do it a little more sophisticated way
with a hydrogen fuel cell which gives you an electrochemical reaction which allows you to have a flow of electrons
in something that looks like a battery which uses hydrogen on one side and uses oxygen on the other side and then
generates water as an output so this is what a hydrogen fuel cell is it's a simple device in a sense but it's
also complicated because you have to design it to be able to last for long periods of time but you can increase your efficiency significantly if you're
using a fuel cell based off of hydrogen compared to a battery compared to direct hydrogen so it's kind of like the holy
grail technology for transportation systems moving forward a lot of opportunities certainly some challenges
all of them which can be overcome with engineering at the end of the day and of course the huge benefit in the context
of aviation is that the output of the fuel cell is water h2o no co2 so that's
what we want at the end of the day is a clean form of efficient energy storage so what we're doing at my company um
called hydroplane which is based in los angeles is developing an aviation specific power plant that operates off
of hydrogen fuel cells and it puts out 200 kilowatts so for anybody who has an electric car you're probably looking at
100 kilowatt system for a small car so you need a little bit more for an aircraft right because you have more potential energy that you have to get to
be able to climb up in altitude and for an aircraft you have to have any system on board be as lightweight as
possible which is the reason why batteries don't work and we're starting simple which i mentioned before the evolutionary use case which is starting
off with a single-engine aircraft that you can see our aircraft above and having it operate on hydrogen to give
you the standard range that we use for a single engine aircraft and the variety
of use cases for this there's many you know one is you know aerial surveillance for forest fires where i live in los
angeles providing cargo for humanitarian aid purposes or even short-range high-value cargo for things like amazon
or simply providing air taxi services to people to get from point a to point b in an island location for example so our
first aircraft for hydroplane is protium and that's a play on words it's the feis first hydrogen isotope is named protium
has the capacity to go a thousand kilometers in range which is pretty far um for a small aircraft because hydrogen
is very efficient and it doesn't go that fast because single engine aircraft never do it goes just over 200
kilometers per hour but when you compare that to a car where you also have traffic it's actually pretty fast so you
can go to many city locations for example using an aircraft like this in a fraction of the time of what it would take you to do on the ground and we're
choosing the simpler platform because the aircraft already exists which means all we need to do is reconfigure the
power plant to be able to support hydrogen storage on board in terms of liquid and then obviously provide the
electricity from the fuel cell to an electric motor and if you have more questions on the engineering side there's a lot of engineering challenges
behind this that i can talk you through after the fact but i won't go through it in more detail right now now the other
advantage of course is that this is a simple aircraft so it has a pilot on board so it doesn't have to deal with
autonomy although that's something that you would like to do in the future the aircraft does has a two-axis autopilot
on board but you know at the end of the day people would love to be able to remove pilots completely from the scenario i don't know if that's ever
going to happen just because there are many off-nominal conditions that you can face whilst you're flying that it's good to have a human being there to make
those kinds of decisions but that certainly is a goal of many people in the aviation space which is to make the aircraft completely
autonomous um in terms of what we're doing in the context of the aircraft development is
the power plant itself so if any of you work on cars you have an idea of what goes under the hood of a car it's not so
different for an aircraft but we obviously don't have an internal combustion engine we have a fuel cell which has been designed specifically for
the aviation use case and power profile we operate out of a field in north los
angeles county which is pretty close to um where the space shuttle used to fly out of we're in a different field of general
aviation field and so our aircraft is getting up and running for its first flight test program um in the next six
months to be operated off of hydrogen and the real advantage is seen by making a comparison between other types of
aircraft that are out there so a internal combustion engine cessna or piper can fly anywhere from four to six
hours we're designing ours to be able to fly for five hours so you can support a range of use cases at five hours whereas
a battery-powered aircraft can only fly for at most one hour with the pipistrel and as little as 14 minutes for the
volocopter multicopter system so you can see how that's kind of a dead end technology which is the reason why you
want to shift over to hydrogen and you think about it more at a system perspective the specific energy of
batteries always stays the same because it's a function of you know the chemical composition of the battery whereas with
hydrogen fuel cell technology you can carry more fuel on board which is hydrogen you can get a better total
specific energy as a result you get more bang for the buck as you have a more complicated
mission going forward and our current goal of course is hydrogen-powered aircraft for small aircraft for
humanitarian aid disaster relief missions primarily um and you can see also here that we've configured it to
carry liquid hydrogen tanks which is very similar to launch vehicles you would have liquid hydrogen it's the best
way to store it on board of an aircraft but of course our future goal is to have a power plant that can put out you know
up to one megawatt which can be used on marine cargo ships and can also be used eventually on larger aircraft like twin
turboprop aircraft and eventually jet aircraft the big challenge though is that inside of the fuel cell itself it
uses a certain type of electrolyte and that electrolyte has to be shifted to something different to support jet
aircraft so we're still looking at 15 to 20 years out for a jet to fly off of hydrogen fuel cells but it can only
happen if you start with something smaller first which is this evolutionary use case and i won't go into the boring
details of the business case behind it but there's a lot of market opportunity for marine for small aircraft and then
for large vehicles on the ground that justifies the development of this technology up to one megawatt for these particular use cases but the goal here
of course is to find those synergies so that you can have decarbonization across the board for the transport sector now
our far term goal for the company of course is to develop fuel cells for a space application because that's
obviously what my background is and one of our partners for our most recent air force proposal is actually nasa johnson
because they're interested in the technology for high durability long-term use for human mars surface missions so
if you're going to go to mars you're not going to have the ability to repair your fuel cell or bring extra parts with you so you're going to have to have it last
for several years and so when you look at it from a durability reliability perspective that's required for aviation
and it's also required for things like long duration service days to the surface of mars or even for a lunar application
for example but this is how you have that evolutionary use case of a technology to be able to support a range
of other technologies going forward so what comes next from the future of flight so i think there is a real
movement afoot to focus aviation technology developments at least for earth-based use cases for commercial
transport for decarbonization right so that's about reducing our carbon output because aircraft are actually relatively
efficient right now when you look at them per passenger kilometer just the challenge that has the co2 output but
when we look at flight in a larger context to include supersonic flight to include suborbital flight to include
space flight there's a lot of work going on in that area as well so i'm sure you've all seen it in the news blue
origin has been conducting its suborbital flight tests with paying or non-paying passengers they recently sent
william shatner up there for his first trip to space and the good news is that you know the blue origin launch vehicle
technology is based off of hydrogen direct as a propellant with liquid oxygen so at least from a carbon
footprint perspective his output is still water it's a good point as to whether or not this is necessary it's a good point as
to whether or not this is actually going to help other technology developments in the space program um or the larger space
economy but the usual goal for the space economy is to reduce the cost per kilogram to orbit so more players in
the field economies of scale can actually reduce the cost but this is being done for space tourism but
there is a follow-on application for this which is to use suborbital flight to get you from city a to city b in a
much faster period of time we all have to ask our question is that a good thing right that's actually reducing that's
potentially increasing carbon footprint because to manufacture these vehicles any manufacturing sector has carbon
output associated with it and right now most hydrogen is not produced as green hydrogen it's not produced by
electrolysis it's produced by a hydroform and recarving a hydrocarbon reforming process which has a co2 output
to it so this thing really isn't carbon free or carbon neutral for that reason so we have to have more investments in

imagine you don't want that hydrogen going towards joy rides you want going towards you know things like necessary travel for
example another implementation of new flight suborbital flight is with virgin

think they had i don't think they've had their first passenger carrying flight i'm sorry paying passenger carrying

they require pilot decision making uh to be able to come back safely and stay within range safety requirements
but it should be up and running i assume the next year for people who want to spend the money on a suborbital space
tourism flight and their architecture is also slightly different in the sense that they take their spacecraft up on an
aircraft called the white knight to a certain altitude and then they deploy the rocket ship so that they have
imparted a certain amount of the potential energy using an aircraft and the rest is carried by the space plane
that you see here and then they fly down to land their glider when they come in and landing so the next aspect of flight which also

station and this can be hydrogen powered because this requires launch vehicle technology and the most efficient launch

production space and primarily you know trips to the space station are done for
um scientific purposes right so whether that's microgravity science or whether it's some sort of you know in vacuum

day that there's a desire for maybe jeff bezos to make a space station or something like that so i think he's uh
he's always got his uh his utopian science fiction mindset at play but right now you can buy a ticket on board
uh spacex to be able to go up to the space station or go in orbit there was a mission only you know about a month ago
probably inspiration for uh which had paying passengers as well as other people who were invited to come along
and i think that will only run you like 50 million dollars so as you can see all of these space

people utilize space as more of a platform and there are many companies in the startup entrepreneurial space who
actually have made business propositions related to manufacturing in space and i've met a lot of these startups sort of

about making fiber optics in space because you're able to make more pristine fiber optic which has less
losses in it and they actually can justify the cost to make the fiber optics in space and bring it back down
because of the improvement in the transmission of the um basically telephone signals in this type of fiber
optic and there's other justifications for making crystalline structures in space you could do all that on board the
international space station for example so it's it's really kind of the sky is not the limit in terms of alternative um
ways that you can utilize spacecraft technology and then of course um the next use case for space flight is
interplanetary cruise from a destination earth to another destination and so that has been
done you know in my lifetime it's only been done um for robotic type of missions but what i'm standing behind
here is the orion capsule which is under development with nasa and other us-based
aerospace companies to send astronauts to perhaps an asteroid to send them to
the moon um to send them to mars and then to have them re-enter earth's atmosphere which is the base of
the architecture of the shape that you see here and it's largely derived off of the apollo vehicle configuration
but you know i think now the question becomes is this going to be a u.s space program effort is it going to be a
international space program airport or is it going to be a commercial venture or a combination of all those things and
